importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: NASA's Fermi Gamma-ray Space Telescope began detecting the mysterious gamma-ray glow in the galactic center shortly after launch in 2008, initiating decades of scientific investigation into its origin.

The Cherenkov Telescope Array Observatory (CTAO), under construction in Chile and Spain, is expected to start returning data by 2027, providing higher-resolution gamma-ray observations that could definitively determine whether the glow is from dark matter or pulsars.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from 2008 to 2025 has seen sustained scientific debate and evolving simulations about the origin of the gamma-ray glow at the center of the Milky Way, with new computer modeling in 2025 offering renewed support for the dark matter hypothesis.

keyTakeAways: Scientists have long puzzled over a mysterious, diffuse glow of gamma rays detected by NASA's Fermi Gamma-ray Space Telescope at the center of the Milky Way.
The glow’s shape, matching the galactic bulge, previously favored the pulsar theory, but new supercomputer simulations show that dark matter collisions could produce a similarly shaped glow.

A 2025 study by Joseph Silk and colleagues at Johns Hopkins University used advanced simulations to show that dark matter in the Milky Way may be squashed into an egg-like shape, closely matching the observed gamma-ray emission pattern.
This finding increases the likelihood that the glow could be due to dark matter, though it does not provide direct proof.
The upcoming Cherenkov Telescope Array Observatory (CTAO), launching in 2027, will offer higher-resolution gamma-ray data to confirm or refute the dark matter explanation.
WIMPs (Weakly Interacting Massive Particles) remain a leading dark matter candidate, as their annihilation could produce the observed gamma rays.
Despite decades of effort, dark matter has never been directly observed, making its nature one of the greatest unsolved mysteries in physics.

The debate between pulsar and dark matter theories continues, with experts like Tracy Slatyer and Chamkaur Ghag acknowledging that while the dark matter hypothesis is plausible, it is not yet definitive.

namedEntities.name: Fermi Gamma-ray Space Telescope
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A NASA space telescope launched in 2008 that detected a mysterious gamma-ray glow at the center of the Milky Way.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Fermi telescope is central to the study because it first detected the gamma-ray glow, which has since become the key data point in the debate over its origin.

namedEntities.name: dark matter
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An invisible, non-luminous form of matter believed to make up about 5 times more of the universe’s matter than visible matter.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Dark matter is the leading alternative explanation for the gamma-ray glow, and the article explores whether new simulations can support its role in producing the observed glow.

namedEntities.name: Joseph Silk
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A professor of physics and astronomy at Johns Hopkins University, coauthor of a 2025 study on dark matter distribution in the Milky Way.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Silk is a key scientist in the article who led the simulation work showing that dark matter in the galactic center could take an egg-shaped form, matching the observed glow.

namedEntities.name: WIMPs (Weakly Interacting Massive Particles)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A leading theoretical candidate for dark matter, particles that would annihilate when colliding and produce detectable gamma rays.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: WIMPs are a core hypothesis for explaining the gamma-ray glow, as their annihilation could produce the observed radiation, and experiments like LZ are designed to detect them.

namedEntities.name: Cherenkov Telescope Array Observatory (CTAO)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A new gamma-ray observatory under construction in Chile and Spain, expected to begin operations in 2027.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: CTAO will provide higher-resolution data than the Fermi telescope, enabling scientists to determine conclusively whether the glow is from dark matter or pulsars.

namedEntities.name: Swiss astronomer Fritz Zwicky
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Swiss astronomer who first theorized dark matter in the 1930s based on observations of galaxy dynamics.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Zwicky’s early work laid the foundation for the dark matter concept, which remains central to modern physics and the search for the substance behind the gamma-ray glow.

namedEntities.name: American astronomers Vera Rubin and W. Kent Ford
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Astronomers who in the 1970s provided strong observational support for dark matter by showing that stars at the edges of galaxies move too quickly to be explained by visible matter alone.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Their work established the scientific credibility of dark matter as a physical reality, making it a serious contender for explaining the galactic glow.

namedEntities.name: LZ Dark Matter Experiment
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A ground-based detector in South Dakota designed to search for WIMP particles by detecting their annihilation products.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: LZ and similar experiments are part of the broader effort to detect WIMPs, which are central to the dark matter explanation of the gamma-ray glow.

namedEntities.name: galactic bulge
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A dense, old-star-rich region at the center of the Milky Way, where the gamma-ray glow is observed.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The glow's shape matches the galactic bulge, which previously suggested a pulsar origin, but new simulations show dark matter could also produce this shape.

namedEntities.name: pulsars
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Neutron stars that are rapidly rotating remnants of exploded stars and a candidate source for gamma-ray emissions.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Pulsars are a traditional alternative explanation for the glow, and the article highlights the ongoing scientific debate between pulsars and dark matter.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Scientists are reevaluating the origin of a mysterious gamma-ray glow detected at the center of the Milky Way by NASA's Fermi Gamma-ray Space Telescope since 2008. While earlier evidence favored pulsars due to the glow's shape matching the galactic bulge, new supercomputer simulations led by Joseph Silk at Johns Hopkins University show that dark matter — specifically, a squashed, egg-shaped distribution — could also produce this pattern. The results suggest a 50% chance the glow stems from dark matter, though no direct detection has been made. The upcoming Cherenkov Telescope Array Observatory (CTAO), set to operate in 2027, will provide higher-resolution data to confirm or reject the dark matter hypothesis. This work reinforces the long-standing scientific quest to identify dark matter, particularly through WIMPs, which remain a leading candidate despite decades of failed direct detection. The discovery would be a breakthrough in physics, potentially solving one of the century-old mysteries of the universe.
title: Mysterious Glow at Center of Milky Way May Be From Dark Matter, Scientists Say
